Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Novel Photobiological Water Treatment Process for More Efficient Water Recovery in Advanced Water Reclamation and Brackish Groundwater Desalination Facilities
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is the potential to impact water scarcity in arid and semi-arid geographies within the US and beyond. The proposed photobiological water treatment process utilizes the natural power of photosynthetic microorganisms (diatoms) and sunlight without the use of hazardous chemicals or non-renewable energy to remove contaminants such as silica, calcium, iron, manganese, phosphorus and nitrogen from the concentrated waste streams (brines) from advanced water reclamation and brackish groundwater desalination facilities. Additional clean, (re)usable water can be obtained from the treated brine quite cost-effectively, while reducing the volume of brine by >50% and producing algal biomass as a marketable by-product. This technology will reduce the environmental impact and also potentially improve the efficiency of water treatment. This Phase I project will have broader impacts on the advancement of science and technology related to environmental microbiology, water reuse and water resource management. The experimental data to be generated in this project could reveal many characteristics and fundamental chemistry and biology of brackish water diatoms that have not been studied in detail, as compared with those found in the freshwater and marine environment.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are to investigate the feasibility of a diatom-based photobiological process for scalant and nutrient removal to recover more fresh water from reverse osmosis concentrate; to characterize the byproducts of this process including organic matter and algal biomass; and to investigate the scale-up challenges. The challenges and opportunities include: (1) the optimization of the biomass growth and constituent removal, including diatom strain screening, (2) impacts of toxic elements, chlorine residuals, salinity, pH, temperature, light sources, intensity, and duration, (3) formation and characterization of byproducts, (4) removal of synthetic organic compounds, such as pharmaceuticals and personal care products, (5) photobiological reactor configuration and hydraulics, and (6) possible uses and economic values of algal biomass. Among them, the major challenges are the possible soluble organic byproduct formation and the relatively modest silica uptake rate. Bench- and pilot-scale experiments will be conducted to optimize the photobiological process to enable a full-scale application with a reasonable footprint. Careful diatom strain/species selection and more detailed chemical and biochemical analyses will also facilitate further process optimization and understanding of the fate of byproducts, their impacts on subsequent desalination, and possible control strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
California, as well as other arid and semi-arid states and countries, rely on non-conventional water resources such as brackish groundwater and recycled water as important sources of their water supply.  Due to the higher concentrations of dissolved chemical constituents, including inorganic and organic compounds, these non-conventional water resources often require high-pressure membrane processes such as reverse osmosis (RO) to reduce the concentration of dissolved constituents and/or salinity.  The RO process recovers near-distilled water quality, highly purified water by filtering out the impurities.  However, the impurities are concentrated in a so-called concentrate or brine stream that represent a smaller fraction of water treated by the process.  The recovery rate of purified water is governed by the quality of the source water and generally falls between 75% and 85%.  Although a higher purified water recovery is desired, the concentrations of certain inorganic constituents such as calcium and silica exceed their solubility limit and start precipitating on the RO membrane surface and cause scaling and fouling at high recovery rates, which ironically reduces the purified water recovery.

In order to improve the RO recovery and reduce the concentrate volume, a unique aqueous silica removal process using naturally occurring diatoms for water reuse and brackish water desalination has been developed by our research group.  A great deal of research work was carried out to further develop the photobiological water treatment technology in this NSF SBIR Phase I project.  The technical objectives of our Phase I research project were to, (1) investigate the feasibility of our diatom-based photobiological process for scalant and nutrient removal to recover more fresh water from reverse osmosis concentrate, (2) characterize the byproducts of this process including organic matter and algal biomass, and (3) investigate the scale-up issue. 

We successfully isolated, identified, and evaluated nine strains of brackish water diatoms from evaporation ponds in Kings County, California and Yuma County, Arizona.  Among the strains tested, Pseudostaurosira trainorii PEWL001 showed a strong potential for its use in the photobiological treatment of RO concentrate.  This diatom strain was successfully used to treat RO concentrate samples from 13 different RO facilities in the Southwest United States, which included six full-scale advanced water purification facilities and six full-scale brackish groundwater desalination facilities, and one pilot-scale brackish water RO facility.  The photobiological treatment was effective to treat all the RO concentrate samples, except for two cases where high concentrations of ammonia appeared to inhibit the growth of brackish water diatoms.  A series of laboratory- and pilot-scale experiments revealed that the photobiological process could remove majorities of different chemical constituents, including silica, calcium, bicarbonate, ammonia, phosphorus, nitrate, iron, and manganese, from the RO concentrate, which enabled additional desalination using another RO process.  The overall purified water recovery could be improved from 85% to 95% with our photobiological technology.  In addition, some trace organic constituents, including N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA), atenolol, benzophenone, and propranolol, were also removed.  The analysis of natural organic matter revealed that the photobiological treatment could transform the organic matter in the RO concentrate by photo-bleaching and photosynthesis, yet no major generation of organic matter was confirmed by the treatment process.  A 15-gallon rooftop pilot reactor was designed, built, and used during this project to test the photobiological process in a more realistic outdoor environment using natural sunlight as a light source.  

Virtually all the research objectives have been met and all the initial technical questions have been answered in this NSF SBIR Phase I research.  It should be noted that the RO concentrate samples from multiple states, including California, Arizona, Texas, and New Mexico, could be treated by our novel photobiological treatment technology to improve purified water recovery.  This clearly demonstrates a wide applicability of our technology to the municipal market in the Southwest United States.  The broader impact/commercial potential of the outcome of our SBIR Phase I is many fold because this new photobiological technology will solve the water scarcity problem in the Southwest United States and other arid and semi-arid countries around the world.  Our green and innovative technology utilizes the natural power of photosynthetic microorganisms (diatoms) and sunlight without the use of hazardous chemicals or non-renewable energy.  Additional clean, purified water can be obtained from the treated brine quite cost-effectively, while reducing the volume of brine by >50% and producing algal biomass as a marketable by-product.  This technology will possibly enable so called carbon neutral or carbon negative water treatment.  A series of peer-reviewed publications and presentations were made, which contributed to the better understanding of the characteristics and fundamental chemistry and biology of brackish water diatoms that have not been studied in detail, as compared with those found in the freshwater and marine environment, and their possible uses in industrial processes.
